titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Wallace Buttrick Papers FA026

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-07-01 00:13:35 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The material in this collection is arranged chronologically, with the clippings and the scrapbooks at the end.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Wallace Buttrick was born on October 3, 1853, on a farm in Potsdam, New York. In 1857, his family moved to Madrid, New York, and later to Ogdensburg where he spent most of his youth.

Mr. Buttrick attended the Ogdensburg Academy and later the Potsdam Normal School. His education was interrupted when his father became ill, and he then secured a job as a messenger in the State Capitol at Albany. This proved unsuitable, and in 1875 he took a position as railroad mail agent between Rome, New York, and Ogdensburg.

In 1880, Mr. Buttrick moved to Rochester where he entered the Divinity School. His first pastorate was the First Baptist Church of New Haven. He was always interested in the West, and he moved to the First Church of St. Paul, Minnesota in 1890. While in Minnesota, Mr. Buttrick engaged in lively controversies with the city administration. In 1892, he moved east to the Emmanuel Church of Albany where he stayed for nearly 10 years.
In 1902, Mr. Buttrick joined the General Education Board as Secretary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Wallace Buttrick collection covers the period from 1888 to 1926.
This collection contains material on the Buttrick family history, Wallace Buttrick's several pastorates, his early work with the China Medical Board, and a trip to England in 1917.
Materials included are two unidentified manuscripts, resolutions, clippings, and a pamphlet.

Important subjects include family history; organization of the China Medical Board; trip to England in 1917; church interests; St. Paul, Minnesota, controversies; education; and Henry Lyman Morehouse.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of Wallace Buttrick were deposited with the Rockefeller Foundation Archives in July 1967 by Mrs. Charles Merrill.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Foundation has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 5 x 8 index card with handwritten genealogy of the Buttrick family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five page typescript family history of the Buttrick family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thirty-nine page typescript history of Wallace Buttrick and immediate family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution adopted by the Church Board on the occasion of Mr. Buttrick's departure from the Albany church.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wallace Buttrick's recollections on his service with the China Medical Board.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recollection of Wallace Buttrick's trip to England at the request of the American ambassador to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint from "The Peabody Journal of Education," vol. 3, no. 3, November 1925. States what education is "in the form of five propositions" I. All Education is Self-Education II. Capacity for Intelligent Self-Direction III. Trained Capacity for Sustained Attention IV. Education is Never Finished; It Is As Long As Life V. The Object of Education is Character, Not Efficiency

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Excerpt from a biography of Henry Lyman Morehouse, in which Buttrick recalls Morehouse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clippings primarily dealing with Buttrick's tenure in St. Paul, Minnesota.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clippings consist primarily of obituaries and testimonials of Buttrick, who died May 27, 1926.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Articles/contributions by Buttrick to various newspapers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Articles concerning St. Paul, Minnesota controversy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Articles and publications on the General Education Board.
